\begin{document}

\maketitle
\tableofcontents
\phantomsection\label{index::doc}


JsHamcrest is a JavaScript library heavily inspired by \href{http://code.google.com/p/hamcrest}{Hamcrest}. It provides
a \emph{large} library of {\hyperref[modules/matchers:module-matchers]{\emph{matcher objects}}} (also known as
constraints or predicates) allowing ``match'' rules to be defined declaratively.
Typical scenarios include testing frameworks, mocking libraries, UI validation
rules and object querying.

This is an open source project licenced under the terms of The
\href{http://www.opensource.org/licenses/bsd-license.php}{BSD License} and sponsored by Destaquenet Technology Solutions, a
brazilian software development and consultancy startup.
\begin{quote}


\strong{See Also:}


PDF version of
this documentation.


\end{quote}


\chapter{Download The Latest Version}
\label{index:download-the-latest-version}\label{index:doc-index}\label{index:jshamcrest-library-of-matcher-objects-for-javascript}
Choose your compression level:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Production -- Minified code, hard to debug

\item {} 
Development -- Uncompressed code, easy to debug

\end{itemize}

JsHamcrest source code is proudly hosted by \href{http://github.com/danielfm/jshamcrest/tree/master}{GitHub}.


\chapter{Documentation Contents}
\label{index:documentation-contents}

\section{Getting Started}
\label{getting_started:getting-started}\label{getting_started::doc}
The first thing to do is download the JsHamcrest source file. You can find the
download links at the {\hyperref[getting_started:doc-index]{\emph{index}}} page.


\subsection{Setting Up The First Example}
\label{getting_started:setting-up-the-first-example}
To be able to use JsHamcrest inside the browser, all you have to do is link the
source file from within your HTML file. For example, create a new file with the
following content and open it on your web browser of choice:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}html}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}header}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}title}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}Page title\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/title\PYGZgt{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}script }\PYG{n+na}{type=}\PYG{l+s}{"text/javascript"} \PYG{n+na}{src=}\PYG{l+s}{"path/to/jshamcrest.js"}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/script\PYGZgt{}}

    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}script }\PYG{n+na}{type=}\PYG{l+s}{"text/javascript"}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
        \PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{odd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Matchers}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{odd}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{n+nx}{alert}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{odd}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{11}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+c1}{// Expected: true}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/script\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/header\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}body}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/body\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/html\PYGZgt{}}
\end{Verbatim}

If an alert message ``true'' pops up when you open the page, then
congratulations!

\begin{notice}{note}{Note:}
Don't forget to change the 4th line to make it point to your actual
JsHamcrest source file.
\end{notice}


\subsection{JsHamcrest Outside The Web Browser}
\label{getting_started:jshamcrest-outside-the-web-browser}
Since JsHamcrest doesn't depend on any browser-specific JavaScript features
(like \code{document}, \code{window}, and so on), you should be able to use
it with any modern stand-alone JavaScript interpreter.

The snippet below shows how to reproduce the previous example using \href{http://www.mozilla.org/rhino/}{Rhino},
a \href{http://java.sun.com/}{Java}-based JavaScript interpreter/compiler developed by \href{http://www.mozilla.org/}{Mozilla}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{js}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n+nx}{load}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'path/to/jshamcrest.js'}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nx}{js}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{odd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Matchers}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{odd}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nx}{js}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n+nx}{odd}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{11}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k+kc}{true}
\PYG{n+nx}{js}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n+nx}{odd}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k+kc}{false}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsubsection{Understanding The Code}
\label{getting_started:understanding-the-code}
On the previous example, you saw the {\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.odd]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.odd()}}} function,
which returns a \emph{matcher object} that checks whether the given number is odd.
In other words, a \emph{matcher} is an object that determines whether two things are
equivalent.

Now try to figure out what the following matchers do:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// Make JsHamcrest matchers globally accessible}
\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{copyMembers}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{this}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{equalTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'10'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}       \PYG{c+c1}{// Expected: true}
\PYG{n+nx}{between}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{and}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+c1}{// Expected: true}
\PYG{n+nx}{greaterThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{Math}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{PI}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+c1}{// Expected: true}
\end{Verbatim}

To make things easier, try to read each statement backwards. For instance:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
...is 10 \textbf{equal to} `10'?

\item {} 
...is 7 \textbf{between} 5 \textbf{and} 10?

\item {} 
...is 4 \textbf{greater than} Math.PI?

\end{itemize}

It's not that hard after all, huh?


\strong{See Also:}


{\hyperref[modules/matchers:module-JsHamcrest.Matchers]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers}}} namespace for the complete list of matchers.




\section{Uses Of JsHamcrest}
\label{uses:uses-of-jshamcrest}\label{uses:mozilla}\label{uses::doc}
Now that you're getting familiar with JsHamcrest, you might be wondering if it
can be used to do any \emph{real} work. Here goes some situations where you might
find JsHamcrest useful.


\subsection{Unit Testing}
\label{uses:unit-testing}
JsHamcrest \emph{is not} a testing framework, but the matcher library provided by
JsHamcrest is very useful for testing since you can build really expressive
test assertions.

For example, take a look at this \href{http://docs.jquery.com/QUnit}{QUnit}-based test suite:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// Integrates JsHamcrest with QUnit}
\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{QUnit}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{\PYGZdl{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{document}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{ready}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nx}{test}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Array might be empty"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{empty}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{n+nx}{test}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"Array might not be empty"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{not}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{empty}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

Besides \href{http://docs.jquery.com/QUnit}{QUnit}, JsHamcrest integrates with several other JavaScript testing
frameworks.


\strong{See Also:}


{\hyperref[modules/integration:module-JsHamcrest.Integration]{\code{JsHamcrest.Integration}}} namespace.




\subsubsection{Mocking Frameworks}
\label{uses:mocking-frameworks}
To further improve your JavaScript testing experience, \href{http://chrisleishman.com/}{Chris Leishman} created
a stub/mock framework called \href{http://jsmockito.org/}{JsMockito}, which uses the matchers provided by
JsHamcrest under the hood.


\subsection{Object Filtering}
\label{uses:object-filtering}
Another great use of matchers is to easily filter lists of objects according to
specific rules.

For example, let's suppose you have a list of objects that represents a people
database:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{people} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Daniel'}\PYG{p}{,}  \PYG{n+nx}{gender}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'M'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Anthony'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{gender}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'M'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{52}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Alicia'}\PYG{p}{,}  \PYG{n+nx}{gender}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'F'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{37}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Maria'}\PYG{p}{,}   \PYG{n+nx}{gender}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'F'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{46}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Carl'}\PYG{p}{,}    \PYG{n+nx}{gender}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'M'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Nicky'}\PYG{p}{,}   \PYG{n+nx}{gender}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'F'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{27}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

Let's create some matchers to be able to filter people by gender or age:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{CustomMatchers} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nx}{male}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{SimpleMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
                \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{gender} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'M'}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

    \PYG{n+nx}{female}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{SimpleMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
                \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{gender} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'F'}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

    \PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{SimpleMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
                \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{age} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{40} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}\PYGZam{}} \PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{age} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{installMatchers}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{CustomMatchers}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}


\strong{See Also:}


{\hyperref[custom_matcher:custom-matchers]{\emph{Writing Custom Matchers}}}.



That's all it takes! Now let's filter some data:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// First, let's make all JsHamcrest stuff globally accessible}
\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{copyMembers}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{this}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{male}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+c1}{// Daniel, Anthony, Carl}
\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{female}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+c1}{// Alicia, Maria, Nicky}
\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+c1}{// Anthony, Maria}
\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{not}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+c1}{// Daniel, Alicia, Carl, Nicky}

\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{either}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{or}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{female}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+c1}{// Anthony, Alicia, Maria, Nicky}
\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{either}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{male}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{or}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+c1}{// Daniel, Anthony, Maria, Carl}

\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{both}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{and}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{female}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+c1}{// Maria}
\PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{people}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{both}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{male}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{and}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+c1}{// Anthony}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Et Cetera}
\label{uses:et-cetera}
We are sure JsHamcrest can do a lot more than what's shown here. If you are
doing something else with JsHamcrest, please {\hyperref[getting_involved:getting-involved]{\emph{let us know}}}!


\section{Writing Custom Matchers}
\label{custom_matcher:custom-matchers}\label{custom_matcher:jsmockito}\label{custom_matcher::doc}\label{custom_matcher:writing-custom-matchers}
JsHamcrest already provides a large set of matchers, but that doesn't mean you
should stick with those. In fact, we encourage you to create your own matchers
every time you feel the need for something more suitable to the problem you
have in hand.


\subsection{A Basic Example}
\label{custom_matcher:a-basic-example}
To introduce you to this topic, we are going to implement a new matcher whose
task is just say whether the actual number is the answer to life, the universe,
and everything. This is not a very useful matcher, but it shows everything you
need to create a basic matcher:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{theAnswerToLifeTheUniverseAndEverything} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{SimpleMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actual}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{actual} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{42}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

        \PYG{n+nx}{describeTo}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'the answer to life, the universe, and everything'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

As you can see, a matcher is nothing more than a function that returns a
{\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}} object . All this particular matcher does is
test whether the actual number is equal to 42.

Okay, let's put that matcher to use:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// Output: Expected the answer to life, the universe, and everything: Success}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{42}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{theAnswerToLifeTheUniverseAndEverything}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+c1}{// Output: Expected the answer to life, the universe, and everything but was 10}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{theAnswerToLifeTheUniverseAndEverything}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsubsection{Do I Need Custom Matchers?}
\label{custom_matcher:do-i-need-custom-matchers}
But wouldn't it be simpler if we just use the
{\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.equalTo]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.equalTo()}}} matcher instead? Let's see an example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// Output: Expected equal to 42: Success}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{42}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{equalTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{42}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+c1}{// Output: Expected equal to 42 but was 10}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{equalTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{42}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

At the end, the result is the same. The only downside though is that we lose
the ability to describe the assertion with a meaningful language, more
appropriate to the problem we need to solve.


\subsubsection{Composing Matchers}
\label{custom_matcher:composing-matchers}
You can use your custom matchers together with the built-in ones to compose even
more interesting match rules. For example, if you want to match when a number
\emph{is not} the answer to life, the universe, and everything, just wrap your custom
matcher with a {\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.not]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.not()}}} matcher and you're done:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// Output: Expected not the answer to life, the universe, and everything: Success}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{not}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{theAnswerToLifeTheUniverseAndEverything}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+c1}{// Output: Expected not the answer to life, the universe, and everything but was 42}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{42}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{not}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{theAnswerToLifeTheUniverseAndEverything}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

That way you get the best of both worlds.


\subsection{Learning By Example}
\label{custom_matcher:learning-by-example}
Another great way to learn how to implement new matchers is to look at the
{\hyperref[modules/matchers:module-matchers]{\emph{existing ones}}}. There's plenty of examples, of various
levels of complexity.

For instance, take a look at the source code of the
{\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.hasSize]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.hasSize()}}} matcher:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Matchers}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{hasSize} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+c1}{// Uses 'equalTo' matcher if the given object is not a matcher}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{!}\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{isMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Matchers}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{equalTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{SimpleMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actual}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actual}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{length}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

        \PYG{n+nx}{describeTo}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'has size '}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{appendDescriptionOf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

        \PYG{n+nx}{describeValueTo}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actual}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actual}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{length}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

This matcher is prepared to use either matchers or numbers as the expected
array size:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{hasSize}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{hasSize}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{lessThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{Distributing Your Custom Set Of Matchers}
\label{custom_matcher:distributing-your-custom-set-of-matchers}
Let's suppose you have a couple of custom matchers you want to distribute to
some people:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// filename: power\PYGZus{}matchers.js}

\PYG{n+nx}{PowerMatchers} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nx}{rocks}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{c+c1}{// ...}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

    \PYG{n+nx}{sucks}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{c+c1}{// ...}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

All you need to do is call {\hyperref[modules/integration:JsHamcrest.Integration.installMatchers]{\code{JsHamcrest.Integration.installMatchers()}}} at the
end of your script, passing the namespace of your matchers as argument:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// filename: power\PYGZus{}matchers.js}

\PYG{n+nx}{PowerMatchers} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+c1}{// ...}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{installMatchers}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{PowerMatchers}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

That's it. To plug your new matcher library, just link your script after
JsHamcrest itself:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}html}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}header}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}title}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}Page title\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/title\PYGZgt{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}script }\PYG{n+na}{type=}\PYG{l+s}{"text/javascript"} \PYG{n+na}{src=}\PYG{l+s}{"path/to/jshamcrest.js"}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/script\PYGZgt{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}script }\PYG{n+na}{type=}\PYG{l+s}{"text/javascript"} \PYG{n+na}{src=}\PYG{l+s}{"path/to/power\PYGZus{}matchers.js"}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/script\PYGZgt{}}

    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}script }\PYG{n+na}{type=}\PYG{l+s}{"text/javascript"}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
        \PYG{c+c1}{// Displays the assertion descriptions using web browser's alert() function}
        \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{WebBrowser}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{obj1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{obj2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{obj1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{rocks}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{obj2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{sucks}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/script\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/header\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}body}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/body\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/html\PYGZgt{}}
\end{Verbatim}


\section{JsHamcrest API Reference}
\label{modules/index:apiref}\label{modules/index::doc}\label{modules/index:jshamcrest-api-reference}
JsHamcrest namespace overview.


\subsection{\texttt{JsHamcrest} --- Main Namespace}
\label{modules/jshamcrest:module-JsHamcrest}\label{modules/jshamcrest:jshamcrest-main-namespace}\label{modules/jshamcrest::doc}\index{JsHamcrest (module)}
Provides the main namespace, along with core abstractions.
\index{areArraysEqual() (in module JsHamcrest)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.areArraysEqual}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.}\bfcode{areArraysEqual}}{\emph{array}, \emph{anotherArray}}{}
Returns whether the arrays \emph{array} and \emph{anotherArray} are equivalent.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{array} -- An array.

\item {} 
\textbf{anotherArray} -- Another array.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
True if both arrays are equivalent; false otherwise.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\subsubsection{\texttt{JsHamcrest.CombinableMatcher} Class}
\label{modules/jshamcrest:jshamcrest-combinablematcher-class}\index{CombinableMatcher (class in JsHamcrest)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.CombinableMatcher}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{JsHamcrest.}\bfcode{CombinableMatcher}}{\emph{\{matches}, \emph{describeTo}, \emph{describeValueTo\}}}{}
Extends {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}}. Defines a composite matcher, that
is, a matcher that wraps several matchers into one.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{matches} -- Function that provides the matching logic.

\item {} 
\textbf{describeTo} -- Function that describes this matcher to a
{\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.Description]{\code{JsHamcrest.Description}}}.

\item {} 
\textbf{describeValueTo} -- \emph{(Optional)} Function that describes the actual value
under test. If not provided, the actual value will be
described as a JavaScript literal.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection{\texttt{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher} Class}
\label{modules/jshamcrest:jshamcrest-simplematcher-class}\index{SimpleMatcher (class in JsHamcrest)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{JsHamcrest.}\bfcode{SimpleMatcher}}{\emph{\{matches}, \emph{describeTo}, \emph{describeValueTo\}}}{}
Extends \code{Object}. Defines a matcher that relies on the external
functions provided by the caller in order to shape the current matching
logic.

Below, an example of matcher that matches middle-aged people:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{middleAged} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{SimpleMatcher}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{age} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{40} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}\PYGZam{}} \PYG{n+nx}{person}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{age} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nx}{describeTo}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{description}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'middle-aged'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+c1}{// Matcher usage}
\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'Gregory'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+c1}{// Expected: true}
\PYG{n+nx}{middleAged}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{matches}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{name}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'Jeniffer'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{age}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{27}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+c1}{// Expected: false}
\end{Verbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{matches} -- Function that provides the matching logic.

\item {} 
\textbf{describeTo} -- Function that describes this matcher to a
{\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.Description]{\code{JsHamcrest.Description}}}.

\item {} 
\textbf{describeValueTo} -- \emph{(Optional)} Function that describes the actual value
under test. If not provided, the actual value will be
described as a JavaScript literal.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection{Core Matchers}
\label{modules/matchers:core-matchers}\index{allOf() (in module JsHamcrest.Matchers)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.allOf}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.}\bfcode{allOf}}{\emph{matchersOrValues...}}{}
All \emph{matchesOrValues} must match the actual value. This matcher behaves
pretty much like the JavaScript \code{\&\&} (and) operator:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{allOf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nx}{greaterThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{lessThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{allOf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{lessThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{allOf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{greaterThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{lessThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{allOf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{lessThan}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\index{raises() (in module JsHamcrest.Matchers)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.raises}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.}\bfcode{raises}}{\emph{exceptionName}}{}
The actual value is a function and, when invoked, it should thrown an
exception with the given name:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{MyException} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{message}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{this}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'MyException'}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{this}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{message} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{message}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{myFunction} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+c1}{// Do something dangerous...}
    \PYG{k}{throw} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{MyException}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'Unexpected error'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{myFunction}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{raises}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'MyException'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{exceptionName} -- Name of the expected exception.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection{Number Matchers}
\label{modules/matchers:number-matchers}\index{between() (in module JsHamcrest.Matchers)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.between}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.}\bfcode{between}}{\emph{start}}{}
The actual number must be between the given range (inclusive):

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{between}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{and}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{start} -- Range start.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Builder object with an \code{end()} method, which returns a
{\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}} instance and thus should be
called to finish the matcher creation.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{closeTo() (in module JsHamcrest.Matchers)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.closeTo}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.}\bfcode{closeTo}}{\emph{expected}\optional{, \emph{delta}}}{}
The actual number must be close enough to \emph{expected}, that is, the actual
number is equal to a value within some range of acceptable error:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{closeTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{closeTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{closeTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{2.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{not}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{closeTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{expected} -- Expected number.

\item {} 
\textbf{delta} -- \emph{(Optional, default=0)} Expected difference delta.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Instance of {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}}.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{str} -- String.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Instance of {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}}.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{filtered} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{even}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\subsubsection{Unit Testing}
\label{modules/operator:unit-testing}\index{assert() (in module JsHamcrest.Operators)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/operator:JsHamcrest.Operators.assert}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Operators.}\bfcode{assert}}{\emph{actualValue}, \emph{matcherOrValue}\optional{, \emph{\{fail}, \emph{pass}, \emph{message\}}}}{}
Generic assert function to be used for easy integration with testing
frameworks. Usage example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{// Add the following method to your testing framework...}

\PYG{k+kd}{function} \PYG{n+nx}{iAssertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actualValue}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{message}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Operators}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{assert}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{actualValue}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{matcherOrValue}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n+nx}{message}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{n+nx}{message}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nx}{fail}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{failMessage}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{c+c1}{// Forward the call to the appropriate method provided by the testing framework}
            \PYG{n+nx}{myTestingFramework}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{fail}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{failMessage}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n+nx}{pass}\PYG{o}{:} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{passMessage}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{c+c1}{// Forward the call to the appropriate method provided by the testing framework}
            \PYG{n+nx}{myTestingFramework}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{pass}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{passMessage}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+c1}{// ...and then you'll be able to leverage the power of JsHamcrest in your test cases}
\PYG{n+nx}{result} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{iAssertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{between}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{and}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{result}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{passed} \PYG{c+c1}{// Output: true}
\PYG{n+nx}{result}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c+c1}{// Output: "50 between 0 and 100: Success"}
\end{Verbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{actualValue} -- Actual value.

\item {} 
\textbf{matcherOrValue} -- Instance of {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}} or a
value.

\item {} 
\textbf{fail} -- \emph{(Optional)} Callback function to be called when
\emph{actualValue} doesn't match \emph{matcherOrValue}.

\item {} 
\textbf{pass} -- \emph{(Optional)} Callback function to be called when
\emph{actualValue} does match \emph{matcherOrValue}.

\item {} 
\textbf{message} -- \emph{(Optional)} Text that describes the assertion on an
even higher level.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Instance of {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.Description]{\code{JsHamcrest.Description}}} with the
assertion description. Also, the result of the assertion
(success or failure/error) can be accessed through the
\code{passed} attribute.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{callTo() (in module JsHamcrest.Operators)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/operator:JsHamcrest.Operators.callTo}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Operators.}\bfcode{callTo}}{\emph{func}\optional{, \emph{arg...}}}{}
Returns a zero-args function that calls the function \emph{func} with the given
\emph{args}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{func} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{callTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{parseInt}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{"2"}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{func}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{sameAs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

This is specially useful when used along with {\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.raises]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.raises()}}}
or {\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.raisesAnything]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.raisesAnything()}}}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{callTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{myFunc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{arg1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{arg2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{raisesAnything}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{func} -- Function to delegate calls to.

\item {} 
\textbf{arg} -- Optional arguments to \emph{func}.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Function that delegates calls to \emph{func}.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{Jasmine -- BDD for your JavaScript}

The following code is an example on how to set up your project:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZlt{}!--}\PYG{c}{ Jasmine dependencies }\PYG{c}{--\PYGZgt{}}

\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}script }\PYG{n+na}{type=}\PYG{l+s}{"text/javascript"} \PYG{n+na}{src=}\PYG{l+s}{"jasmine-html.js"}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/script\PYGZgt{}}

    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

            \PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{calc}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{add}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{equalTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\paragraph{JsTestDriver -- Remote JavaScript Console}
\label{modules/integration:jstestdriver-remote-javascript-console}\index{JsTestDriver() (in module JsHamcrest.Integration)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{modules/integration:JsHamcrest.Integration.JsTestDriver}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{JsHamcrest.Integration.}\bfcode{JsTestDriver}}{\emph{\{scope\}}}{}
Integrates JsHamcrest with \href{http://code.google.com/p/js-test-driver/}{JsTestDriver}. Instructions on how to set up
your project:
\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Let's assume your project root directory have a \code{lib}
directory to keep your project's dependencies. In this case, copy
the \code{jshamcrest.js} file to that directory;

\item {} 
Create a file \code{plugin/jshamcrest-plugin.js} in
your project root directory and put one of the following lines inside
it:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{JsTestDriver}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+c1}{// Same as above}
\PYG{n+nx}{JsHamcrest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{Integration}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{JsTestDriver}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nx}{scope}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{k}{this}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

\item {} 
Finally, edit the \code{jsTestDriver.conf} file as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{load}\PYG{o}{:}
  \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n+nx}{lib}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{js}
  \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nx}{source} \PYG{n+nx}{directory}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
  \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nx}{test} \PYG{n+nx}{cases} \PYG{n+nx}{directory}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
  \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n+nx}{plugin}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{js}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{enumerate}

That's it. Your test cases should now have access to JsHamcrest functions:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nx}{CalculatorTest} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nx}{TestCase}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'CalculatorTest'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n+nx}{CalculatorTest}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{prototype}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{testAdd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kd}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k+kd}{var} \PYG{n+nx}{calc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{new} \PYG{n+nx}{MyCalculator}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n+nx}{assertThat}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nx}{calc}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n+nx}{add}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nx}{equalTo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{scope} -- \emph{(Optional, default=this)} Copies all matchers to the given
scope.

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
Nothing.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\section{Getting Involved}
\label{getting_involved:getting-involved}\label{getting_involved::doc}\label{getting_involved:yuitest}\label{getting_involved:id1}
As with any open source project, there are several ways you can help:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Report bugs, feature requests and other issues in the
\href{http://github.com/danielfm/jshamcrest/issues}{issue tracking system};

\item {} 
Submit patches to reported issues (both those you find, or that others have
filed);

\item {} 
Help with the documentation by pointing out areas that are lacking or unclear,
and if you are so inclined, submitting patches to correct it;

\item {} 
Improve the overall project quality by suggesting refactorings and improving
the test cases. A great way to learn -- and in turn give value back to the
community -- is to review someone else's code. So, we invite you to review
ours;

\item {} 
Write about JsHamcrest in your blog or personal web site. Let your friends
know about this project.

\end{itemize}

Your participation is much appreciated. Keep up with JsHamcrest development on
\href{http://github.com/danielfm/jshamcrest/tree/master}{GitHub}.


\subsection{How Do I Join The Team?}
\label{getting_involved:how-do-i-join-the-team}
JsHamcrest is a mature project and it's probably not going to get lots of new
features. But those that the developers notice participating to a high extent
will be invited to join the team as a committer.

This is as much based on personality and ability to work with other developers
and the community as it is with proven technical ability. Being unhelpful to
other users, or obviously looking to become a committer for bragging rights and
nothing else is frowned upon, as is asking to be made a committer without having
contributed sufficiently to be invited.


\subsection{Contact Information}
\label{getting_involved:contact-information}\begin{quote}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Author}] \leavevmode
Daniel Fernandes Martins \textless{}\href{mailto:daniel@destaquenet.com}{daniel@destaquenet.com}\textgreater{}

\item[{Company}] \leavevmode
\href{http://www.destaquenet.com/}{Destaquenet Technology Solutions}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\end{quote}


\section{Changelog}
\label{changelog:destaquenet-technology-solutions}\label{changelog::doc}\label{changelog:changelog}
Like any other piece of software, JsHamcrest is evolving at each release.
Here you can track our progress:

\textbf{Version 0.6.7} \emph{(Sep 11, 2011)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Updated {\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.hasSize]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.hasSize()}}} function to make it work with
objects;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6.6} \emph{(Jun 23, 2011)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Fixed broken logic of {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.areArraysEqual]{\code{JsHamcrest.areArraysEqual()}}} function;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6.5} \emph{(Jun 20, 2011)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Description of the Function literal now includes function name when
available;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6.4} \emph{(May 25, 2011)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Updated \code{hasMember} matcher to make it possible to also match considering
the member's value;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6.3} \emph{(Apr 23, 2011)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Integration with Jasmine;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6.2} \emph{(Sep 30, 2010)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Added {\hyperref[modules/operator:JsHamcrest.Operators.callTo]{\code{JsHamcrest.Operators.callTo()}}} function, which makes
{\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.raises]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.raises()}}} and
{\hyperref[modules/matchers:JsHamcrest.Matchers.raisesAnything]{\code{JsHamcrest.Matchers.raisesAnything()}}} easier to use.

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6.1} \emph{(Dec 22, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Fixed the code that removes useless stacktrace entries when using JsHamcrest
with js-test-driver;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.6} \emph{(Nov 22, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Build script rewritten from scratch with \href{http://python.org/}{Python};

\item {} 
Documentation rewritten from scratch with \href{http://sphinx.pocoo.org/}{Sphinx};

\item {} 
Added a couple of new matchers;

\item {} 
New {\hyperref[modules/operator:module-JsHamcrest.Operators]{\code{JsHamcrest.Operators}}} namespace;

\item {} 
Several improvements and fixes;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.5.2} \emph{(Jul 19, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
JSLint fixes;

\item {} 
Integration with screw-unit (thanks, Chris Leishman!)

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.5.1} \emph{(Jul 11, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Added a new function to {\hyperref[modules/jshamcrest:JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher]{\code{JsHamcrest.SimpleMatcher}}} that provides a
better way to describe the actual value;

\item {} 
Added a couple of new matchers;

\item {} 
Improvements on test code;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.4} \emph{(May 26, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Integration with JsTestDriver and JsUnity;

\item {} 
Some code cleanup;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.3} \emph{(May 23, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Integration with QUnit;

\item {} 
Improvements on integration code;

\item {} 
Added some integration tests;

\item {} 
Documentation improvements;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.2} \emph{(May 22, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Fixed small API documentation issues;

\item {} 
Download page link in README;

\item {} 
{\hyperref[modules/operator:JsHamcrest.Operators.assert]{\code{JsHamcrest.Operators.assert()}}} function now accepts a string that
describes the assertion;

\item {} 
Refactoring to allow easy integration with JavaScript testing frameworks;

\end{itemize}

\textbf{Version 0.1} \emph{(April 21, 2009)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
First public release;

\end{itemize}
